author: Lucie Philippon
title: Introduction to French AI Policy
summary: France's approach to AI governance, as detailed in a recent report by a government-appointed committee, prioritizes French competitiveness and leadership in AI development, downplaying potential risks and advocating for open-source AI and international collaboration. The report's optimistic stance contrasts with concerns about potential negative consequences of unchecked AI advancement.

author: Remmelt
title: Fifteen Lawsuits against OpenAI
summary: Numerous US-based lawsuits target OpenAI, primarily focusing on copyright infringement but also encompassing privacy violations, libel claims, and accusations of mission betrayal. Future litigation is anticipated to center on data rights, worker rights, product liability, and environmental concerns.

author: jacquesthibs
title: Pausing AI Developments Isn't Enough. We Need to Shut it All Down by Eliezer Yudkowsky
summary: Eliezer Yudkowsky argues that preventing potential human extinction from advanced AI requires an immediate, indefinite, and worldwide moratorium on large AI training runs, enforced through international cooperation and potentially forceful measures; he contends that less drastic actions are insufficient to mitigate the extreme risks involved.

author: abramdemski
title: Some Thoughts on AI Art
summary: The article argues that while the use of copyrighted material to train AI art generators isn't currently illegal, it raises significant ethical concerns. The author contends that these AI systems, even if not directly reproducing copyrighted works, profit illegitimately from artists' creations, threatening their livelihoods and potentially shaping future AI policy.

author: Ricki Heicklen
title: Toward a Broader Conception of Adverse Selection
summary: President Biden's October 30, 2023 executive order on AI outlines numerous deadlines for various federal agencies to submit reports, develop strategies, and implement initiatives related to AI development, deployment, workforce, and risk mitigation, spanning from late November 2023 to January 2024 and beyond.

author: Evan Hubinger
title: AI - AI Alignment Forum
summary: Artificial intelligence alignment focuses on ensuring powerful AI systems act according to human values, addressing the risk of unintended consequences and existential threats. This field encompasses various approaches, from narrow goals (e.g., curing disease) to broader aspirations for beneficial AI, and involves theoretical research, engineering solutions, and organizational efforts.

author: jefftk
title: Machine Learning Consent
summary: The increasing power of AI models trained on vast datasets raises copyright concerns, as they can reproduce copyrighted material, potentially violating fair use principles. This necessitates legal and ethical discussions regarding unauthorized data use and the potential for widespread technological unemployment.

title: Cultural Heritage and Internet of Things
abstract: Ancient structures and historical buildings represent invaluable assets for future generations. They need to be preserved as much as possible since, as cultural heritage, provide with irreplaceable cultural, social and historical wealth, not only for the local heir communities, but in many cases for the whole human kind. In the context of today's technologies, the Internet of Things (IoT) paradigm represents one of the most effective ways for monitoring "things" around us. Cultural Heritage stays as one important application field for IoT, since conservation of cultural heritage sites can be significantly improved by means of an efficient and well-designed monitoring and control system. However, there are many approaches to apply IoT on Cultural Heritage use cases. For this reason, in this paper we discuss IoT architectures currently used for monitoring and preservation of historical buildings, and identify existing challenges IoT applications are still facing to become a fundamental part in the conservation of the everlasting cultural values these buildings represent.
summary: This paper examines the application of Internet of Things (IoT) technology to cultural heritage preservation, specifically focusing on monitoring and control systems for historical buildings. It analyzes existing IoT architectures and identifies challenges hindering widespread adoption of this technology in safeguarding cultural values.
